data.title: Great museum with a nice gift shop
data.text: We wandered by on congress street and stopped in. Unique art and a great gift shop. Free on Sundays!

data.title: Small unique museum
data.text: Relatively small collection of changing exhibits. The display of various "Day of the Dead" altars (including one for pets) was interesting. Good for an hour or so of exposure to styles you might not encounter elsewhere.

data.title: Hidden Treasure
data.text: We were thrilled with this gem of a gallery.  Latino focused, wonderful art and I learned some history too.  Well worth the modest admission price.  Great gift shop too.

data.title: Very cool place to visit in Downtown
data.text: I love going to Mexi-Arte for their different shows and events. They put together a great Dia De Los Muertos parade and events every year.

data.title: Hidden Gem-Worth the Visit
data.text: We were walking towards the hotel when I had to stop and take some pictures of street art.  Low and behold, there was an entire museum devoted to Mexican inspired street art by Mexican Americans living in Texas.  Not only does it follow the "vibe" of Texas, but the pieces on display were incredibly well chosen and embodied a pop-art spirit that is sometimes missing from larger museums.  There were multimedia exhibits, as well as larger format paintings.  I would definitely recommend that anyone in Austin make a stop here.

data.title: A lively surprise in downtown Austin
data.text:
We were heading for a "women's art gallery" somewhere nearby, but that place didn't open until noon and so we went to the next art museum on our list, namely this one.  What a fun surprise it turned out to be!  

The gallery was not large or extensive, and not expensive to enter, but had a delightful range of very professional ethnically-themed exhibits relating to the Mexican/American cultural experience, and we much enjoyed perusing each display.  Some familiarity with hispanic culture wouldn't hurt, but isn't a requirement.  The exhibits were by turns funny, tragic, thought-provoking and remarkably well crafted and presented.  A large function was setting up in the big hall, but didn't get in the way and we had plenty of time to explore the works on display around it.  The gift shop is a lot of fun, and as it was Father's Day, my spouse purchased me an EXCELLENT "Dia de Los Muertos" sugar-skull necktie that has since garnered me a great deal of hip-cred.  I also bought my daughter a totally cool skull-n-crossbones tea infusion gizmo that she adores.  

Recommended.

data.title: Great attraction in Austin!
data.text: The Museum is small, but it was worth it for the price we paid. It is located within walking distance of the Texas State Capitol, and there are many interesting paintings inside. I loved the Frida Kahlo souvenirs, I wanted to buy them all. The souvenir shop has many options and at a reasonable cost. Good shopping options around the area and beautiful street art pictures. It will probably take you less than an hour to walk around the entire museum and the souvenir shop.

data.title: Cool Museum / Art Gallery
data.text: Nice museum / art gallery, located in a good spot downtown for a walk-in while your out doing other things. The exhibit / show I saw was a collection of prints. In museum dollars, the cost ($5.00). initially seemed excessive, but after I viewed the artwork - it became more of a donation that I was happy to make. Nice gift shop with some cool luchador masks.

data.title: Not worth 5 dollars
data.text: Not a museum, a gallery actually, very small and staff is rude. Not worth your time for parking and money. Go someplace else.

data.title: Good respresentive of Mexic-art
data.text:
While not my type of art, I appreciated the free expedition on display at the museum.  The gift shop is very sweet!
I would recommend this place to help gain better understanding of this art genre.

data.title: Free In December
data.text: I won't disagree this place was small but it is free in December and one of the main reasons I went. There was a display on of art from different people, and everything was for sale. Additionally a Christmas nativity scene display. It was a quick visit and there was a pretty nice gift shop. Not a lot to say really.

data.title: Great value
data.text: I've always been intrigued by Dia de Los Muertos and after viewing the exhibit, I understand it better. The alters from each area of Mexico were beautiful. The back room filled will news clippings of the city's history of the day of the dead parade was very interesting as well. I'll admit, it's not a lot to see and with a 3 year old, it can be challenging, but it was a great way to cool off and see some art. The gift shop had lots of cool stuff for all ages, including some great spanish color books.

data.title: El Dia de Los Muertos
data.text:
This museum focuses on El Dia de Los Muertos - The Day of the Dead. It has a lot of interesting information and shows altars to honor the dead. It is very beautiful. However, there is a back room that shows you the progression of the holiday throughout the past 30 years. There's tables with belongings on them. A lot of it is newspaper clippings. There's not much good information or big enough to read and grasp. It's a lot of getting super close and reading long newspaper clippings.. so we kind of skipped through that area. There was only one staff member to interact with and he was not friendly.

The museum store was a little pricey, as they all are, but it was very nice.

data.title: Interesting to visit & Great shop
data.text: We went on a Sunday to the museum which we came to realize meant it was free to enter the exhibition. It is an interesting contemporary Mexican art museum. I'm not sure I would have paid the full price (around $5 I think) for it, but it would have been supporting a local museum so that makes it worth it. The shop was fun to look at with traditional Mexican souvenirs, although was a bit on the pricey end probably because of where it is on Congress street.

data.title: A Downtown Highlight
data.text:
I'VE BEEN A MEMBER SINCE THEIR BEGINNING

They do an outstanding job of focusing on the Hispanic threads woven into the Texas and regional, and even international art scene.

Located in downtown Austin...also has a terrific gift shop.

data.title: Interesting small museum, very nice gift store
data.text: This is a small museum, takes about 1/2 hour to go through it. The art is contemporary, and quite interesting. The gift shop has a lot of Day of the Dead-themed items, which my grandsons were interested in because they have been watching the movie Book of Life.

data.title: Unexpected Pleasure
data.text: We found ourselves in the heart of Austin's business/gov't. district by mistake, while looking for artsy things to do. The Mexic-Arte Museum was right around the corner and had a low entry fee, so we thought, why not? The museum is small, but powerful. Street art, installations, avant-garde art, and more traditional pieces are a feast for the eyes and make you think. Be sure to read the descriptions next to the artwork. Museum and gift shop (with unusual stuff and reasonable prices) help support new artists. We never would have visited this museum if we hadn't been "stuck," but we're really glad we did.

data.title: Complete Let Down
data.text: Was super excited to come check this place out. Especially after seeing online they had a Dia de los Muertos exhibit. Small gallery, which I would not have minded except for the fact the few pieces of art they did have were not too exciting. They had a whole wall of news papers with a bunch holes punched out of them using a hole punch, nothing else done to them, and then put in a simple white frame ?!?!?!?!? Im pretty open when it comes to art, but what is artistic about that? Spent more time in their gift shop then I did in their gallery.

data.title: Pleasant Downtown Museum
data.text: Modest admission price ($10) with a fun exhibit of modern Latina art of several different media. The serigraphs were particularly dramatic.

data.title: Don't Waste Your Time
data.text: As my wife is Mexican, we thought this might be an interesting museum to visit.  Unfortunately, the sparse exhibits were poorly put together, which left visitors with the feeling of having looked at a small hodgepodge of materials.
